text:
Oil and Natural Gas Corporation Ltd.'s (ONGC) plan to invest Rs 78,000 crore for development of oil and gas discoveries in Andhra Pradesh may impact the credit rating of the government-run company, Moody's Investors Service said in an analysis report.The large investment will be credit negative for the company, according to the report on ONGC’s latest plans announced on January 28, 2017. Of the total investment, around Rs 10,000 crore will be spent on onshore blocks, and the balance Rs 68,000 crore on offshore assets in the Krishna-Godavari (KG) basin. The company expects to commence investment in financial year (FY) 2017-18 and finish by FY21.








The huge capital outlay will be credit negative for ONGC and lead to an upfront increase in leverage. At the same time, the development of oil and gas assets has a long gestation period before contributing meaningfully to earnings and cash flows.Moody’s Analysis Report






Assuming that the investment is spread equally over FY18 and FY19, ONGC's cash-flow-to-debt ratio is expected to decline to 40 percent by March 2018 and 33 percent by March 2019, it added.If ONGC takes on this investment, it will not leave any room for the company to increase its debt, the report said.However, the oil and gas major’s sizeable cash balances worth Rs 25,800 crore as of March 31, 2016 supports its baseline credit assessment, which reflects its fundamental Baa1 credit strength, added the report. During the initial development period, ONGC’s borrowings will remain elevated for its Baa1 rating category.

title: ONGC’s Rs 78,000-Crore Investment Plan Likely To Hit Its Credit Rating: Moody’s
